title.en: Genealogical Tables of the Three Dynasties

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：五帝、三代之記，尚矣。

translations.literal: The Grand Historian says: The records of the Five Emperors and Three Dynasties are already ancient.
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian says: The records of the Five Emperors and Three Dynasties are already ancient.

sentences.zh: 自殷以前諸侯不可得而譜，周以來乃頗可著。

translations.literal: Before the Yin dynasty, the feudal lords cannot be properly arranged in genealogical tables; since the Zhou, they can be quite well recorded.
translations.idiomatic: Before the Yin dynasty, the feudal lords cannot be properly arranged in genealogical tables; since the Zhou, they can be quite well recorded.

sentences.zh: 孔子因史文次春秋，紀元年，正時日月，蓋其詳哉。

translations.literal: Confucius followed the historical texts to arrange the Spring and Autumn Annals, recording the first year, correcting the days and months—how detailed it is!
translations.idiomatic: Confucius followed the historical texts to arrange the Spring and Autumn Annals, recording the first year, correcting the days and months—how detailed it is!

sentences.zh: 至於序尚書則略，無年月；

translations.literal: As for arranging the Documents, it is brief, without years and months;
translations.idiomatic: As for arranging the Documents, it is brief, without years and months;

sentences.zh: 或頗有，然多闕，不可錄。

translations.literal: some have them to some extent, but many are missing and cannot be recorded.
translations.idiomatic: some have them to some extent, but many are missing and cannot be recorded.

sentences.zh: 故疑則傳疑，蓋其慎也。

translations.literal: Therefore, where there is doubt, transmit the doubt—this is his carefulness.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore, where there is doubt, transmit the doubt—this is his carefulness.

translations.literal: The Grand Historian says: The records of the Five Emperors and Three Dynasties are already ancient. Before the Yin dynasty, the feudal lords cannot be properly arranged in genealogical tables; since the Zhou, they can be quite well recorded. Confucius followed the historical texts to arrange the Spring and Autumn Annals, recording the first year, correcting the days and months—how detailed it is! As for arranging the Documents, it is brief, without years and months; some have them to some extent, but many are missing and cannot be recorded. Therefore, where there is doubt, transmit the doubt—this is his carefulness.

sentences.zh: 余讀諜記，黃帝以來皆有年數。

translations.literal: I have read the secret records; since the Yellow Emperor, all have year numbers.
translations.idiomatic: I have read the secret records; since the Yellow Emperor, all have year numbers.

sentences.zh: 稽其歷譜諜終始五德之傳，古文咸不同，乖異。

translations.literal: Examining their calendar genealogies and secret records, the transmission of the beginning and end of the Five Virtues—all the ancient texts differ and are contradictory.
translations.idiomatic: Examining their calendar genealogies and secret records, the transmission of the beginning and end of the Five Virtues—all the ancient texts differ and are contradictory.

sentences.zh: 夫子之弗論次其年月，豈虛哉！

translations.literal: That the Master did not discuss and arrange their years and months—was this in vain?
translations.idiomatic: That the Master did not discuss and arrange their years and months—was this in vain?

sentences.zh: 於是以五帝系諜、尚書集世紀黃帝以連山訖共和為世表。

translations.literal: Therefore, using the Five Emperors genealogical records and Documents collected generations, I made genealogical tables from the Yellow Emperor down to the Gonghe period.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore, using the Five Emperors genealogical records and Documents collected generations, I made genealogical tables from the Yellow Emperor down to the Gonghe period.

translations.literal: I have read the secret records; since the Yellow Emperor, all have year numbers. Examining their calendar genealogies and secret records, the transmission of the beginning and end of the Five Virtues—all the ancient texts differ and are contradictory. That the Master did not discuss and arrange their years and months—was this in vain? Therefore, using the Five Emperors genealogical records and Documents collected generations, I made genealogical tables from the Yellow Emperor down to the Gonghe period.

sentences.zh: 張夫子問褚先生曰：「詩言契、后稷皆無父而生。

translations.literal: Zhang Fuzi asked Master Chu: 'The Poetry says that Xie and Hou Ji were both born without fathers.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Fuzi asked Master Chu: 'The Poetry says that Xie and Hou Ji were both born without fathers.

sentences.zh: 今案諸傳記咸言有父，父皆黃帝子也，得無與詩謬秋？」

translations.literal: Now examining the various transmitted records, all say they had fathers, and their fathers were all sons of the Yellow Emperor—could this not contradict the Poetry?'
translations.idiomatic: Now examining the various transmitted records, all say they had fathers, and their fathers were all sons of the Yellow Emperor—could this not contradict the Poetry?'

translations.literal: Zhang Fuzi asked Master Chu: 'The Poetry says that Xie and Hou Ji were both born without fathers. Now examining the various transmitted records, all say they had fathers, and their fathers were all sons of the Yellow Emperor—could this not contradict the Poetry?'

sentences.zh: 褚先生曰：「不然。

translations.literal: Master Chu said: 'Not so.
translations.idiomatic: Master Chu said: 'Not so.

sentences.zh: 詩言契生於卵，后稷人跡者，欲見其有天命精誠之意耳。

translations.literal: The Poetry speaks of Xie being born from an egg, Hou Ji from a footprint, wishing to show that they had the intention of heavenly mandate and sincerity.
translations.idiomatic: The Poetry speaks of Xie being born from an egg, Hou Ji from a footprint, wishing to show that they had the intention of heavenly mandate and sincerity.

sentences.zh: 鬼神不能自成，須人而生，柰何無父而生乎！

translations.literal: Spirits and gods cannot complete themselves; they must be born through humans—how could they be born without fathers?
translations.idiomatic: Spirits and gods cannot complete themselves; they must be born through humans—how could they be born without fathers?

sentences.zh: 一言有父，一言無父，信以傳信，疑以傳疑，故兩言之。

translations.literal: One account says they had fathers, another says no fathers; transmit what is trustworthy as trustworthy, transmit doubt as doubt—therefore both accounts are given.
translations.idiomatic: One account says they had fathers, another says no fathers; transmit what is trustworthy as trustworthy, transmit doubt as doubt—therefore both accounts are given.

sentences.zh: 堯知契、稷皆賢人，天之所生，故封之契七十里，後十餘世至湯，王天下。

translations.literal: Yao knew that Xie and Ji were both worthy men, born of Heaven, so he enfeoffed Xie with seventy li, and after more than ten generations reached Tang, who ruled All Under Heaven.
translations.idiomatic: Yao knew that Xie and Ji were both worthy men, born of Heaven, so he enfeoffed Xie with seventy li, and after more than ten generations reached Tang, who ruled All Under Heaven.

sentences.zh: 堯知后稷子孫之後王也，故益封之百里，其後世且千歲，至文王而有天下。

translations.literal: Yao knew that Hou Ji's descendants would later rule, so he additionally enfeoffed him with a hundred li; his descendants lasted a thousand years, until King Wen possessed All Under Heaven.
translations.idiomatic: Yao knew that Hou Ji's descendants would later rule, so he additionally enfeoffed him with a hundred li; his descendants lasted a thousand years, until King Wen possessed All Under Heaven.

sentences.zh: 詩傳曰：『湯之先為契，無父而生。

translations.literal: The Poetry transmission says: 'Tang's ancestor was Xie, born without a father.
translations.idiomatic: The Poetry transmission says: 'Tang's ancestor was Xie, born without a father.

sentences.zh: 契母與姊妹浴於玄丘水，有燕銜卵墮之，契母得，故含之，誤吞之，即生契。

translations.literal: Xie's mother and her sisters were bathing in the Xuanhill waters when a swallow carried an egg and dropped it; Xie's mother got it, so she cherished it, mistakenly swallowed it, and thus gave birth to Xie.
translations.idiomatic: Xie's mother and her sisters were bathing in the Xuanhill waters when a swallow carried an egg and dropped it; Xie's mother got it, so she cherished it, mistakenly swallowed it, and thus gave birth to Xie.

sentences.zh: 契生而賢，堯立為司徒，姓之曰子氏。

translations.literal: Xie was born and was worthy; Yao established him as Minister of Education, and gave him the surname Zi.
translations.idiomatic: Xie was born and was worthy; Yao established him as Minister of Education, and gave him the surname Zi.

sentences.zh: 子者茲；

translations.literal: Zi means 'this';
translations.idiomatic: Zi means 'this';

sentences.zh: 茲，益大也。

translations.literal: 'this' means increasingly great.
translations.idiomatic: 'this' means increasingly great.

sentences.zh: 詩人美而頌之曰「殷社芒芒，天命玄鳥，降而生商」。

translations.literal: The poets praised and eulogized him, saying 'The Yin fields are vast, heavenly mandate dark bird, descended and gave birth to Shang'.
translations.idiomatic: The poets praised and eulogized him, saying 'The Yin fields are vast, heavenly mandate dark bird, descended and gave birth to Shang'.

sentences.zh: 商者質，殷號也。

translations.literal: Shang means solid, Yin is the title.
translations.idiomatic: Shang means solid, Yin is the title.

sentences.zh: 文王之先為后稷，后稷亦無父而生。

translations.literal: King Wen's ancestor was Hou Ji; Hou Ji was also born without a father.
translations.idiomatic: King Wen's ancestor was Hou Ji; Hou Ji was also born without a father.

sentences.zh: 后稷母為姜嫄，出見大人蹟而履踐之，知於身，則生后稷。

translations.literal: Hou Ji's mother was Jiang Yuan; she went out and saw giant footprints, stepped in them, became pregnant in her body, and gave birth to Hou Ji.
translations.idiomatic: Hou Ji's mother was Jiang Yuan; she went out and saw giant footprints, stepped in them, became pregnant in her body, and gave birth to Hou Ji.

sentences.zh: 姜嫄以為無父，賤而棄之道中，牛羊避不踐也。

translations.literal: Jiang Yuan considered him fatherless, lowly, and abandoned him on the road; oxen and sheep avoided and did not trample him.
translations.idiomatic: Jiang Yuan considered him fatherless, lowly, and abandoned him on the road; oxen and sheep avoided and did not trample him.

sentences.zh: 抱之山中，山者養之。

translations.literal: She carried him to the mountains; the mountains nourished him.
translations.idiomatic: She carried him to the mountains; the mountains nourished him.

sentences.zh: 又捐之大澤，鳥覆席食之。

translations.literal: Again she abandoned him in a great marsh; birds covered him with wings and fed him.
translations.idiomatic: Again she abandoned him in a great marsh; birds covered him with wings and fed him.

sentences.zh: 姜嫄怪之，於是知其天子，乃取長之。

translations.literal: Jiang Yuan was astonished, so knew he was a Son of Heaven, and took and raised him.
translations.idiomatic: Jiang Yuan was astonished, so knew he was a Son of Heaven, and took and raised him.

sentences.zh: 堯知其賢才，立以為大農，姓之曰姬氏。

translations.literal: Yao knew of his worthy talents, established him as Grand Minister of Agriculture, and gave him the surname Ji.
translations.idiomatic: Yao knew of his worthy talents, established him as Grand Minister of Agriculture, and gave him the surname Ji.

sentences.zh: 姬者，本也。

translations.literal: Ji means root.
translations.idiomatic: Ji means root.

sentences.zh: 詩人美而頌之曰「厥初生民」，深修益成，而道后稷之始也。』

translations.literal: The poets praised and eulogized him, saying 'At first he gave birth to the people', deeply cultivating and completing, and thus the beginning of Hou Ji's way.'
translations.idiomatic: The poets praised and eulogized him, saying 'At first he gave birth to the people', deeply cultivating and completing, and thus the beginning of Hou Ji's way.'

sentences.zh: 孔子曰：『昔者堯命契為子氏，為有湯也。

translations.literal: Confucius said: 'In former times Yao commanded Xie to be of the Zi surname, because there would be Tang.
translations.idiomatic: Confucius said: 'In former times Yao commanded Xie to be of the Zi surname, because there would be Tang.

sentences.zh: 命后稷為姬氏，為有文王也。

translations.literal: He commanded Hou Ji to be of the Ji surname, because there would be King Wen.
translations.idiomatic: He commanded Hou Ji to be of the Ji surname, because there would be King Wen.

sentences.zh: 大王命季歷，明天瑞也。

translations.literal: King Tai commanded Ji Li to receive the bright auspicious signs.
translations.idiomatic: King Tai commanded Ji Li to receive the bright auspicious signs.

sentences.zh: 太伯之吳，遂生源也。』

translations.literal: Tai Bo went to Wu, thus establishing the source.'
translations.idiomatic: Tai Bo went to Wu, thus establishing the source.'

sentences.zh: 天命難言，非聖人莫能見。

translations.literal: Heaven's mandate is difficult to speak of; only sages can perceive it.
translations.idiomatic: Heaven's mandate is difficult to speak of; only sages can perceive it.

sentences.zh: 舜、禹、契、后稷皆黃帝子孫也。

translations.literal: Shun, Yu, Xie, and Hou Ji were all Yellow Emperor descendants.
translations.idiomatic: Shun, Yu, Xie, and Hou Ji were all Yellow Emperor descendants.

sentences.zh: 黃帝策天命而治天下，德澤深後世，故其子孫皆復立為天子，是天之報有德也。

translations.literal: The Yellow Emperor received Heaven's mandate and governed All Under Heaven; his virtue and favor deeply benefited later generations, therefore his descendants all again became established as Sons of Heaven—this is Heaven's reward for virtue.
translations.idiomatic: The Yellow Emperor received Heaven's mandate and governed All Under Heaven; his virtue and favor deeply benefited later generations, therefore his descendants all again became established as Sons of Heaven—this is Heaven's reward for virtue.

sentences.zh: 人不知，以為閒從布衣匹夫起耳。

translations.literal: People do not know this, thinking it was from humble origins as commoners suddenly rising.
translations.idiomatic: People do not know this, thinking it was from humble origins as commoners suddenly rising.

sentences.zh: 夫布衣匹夫安能無故而起王天下乎？

translations.literal: How could commoners without cause suddenly rise and rule All Under Heaven?
translations.idiomatic: How could commoners without cause suddenly rise and rule All Under Heaven?

sentences.zh: 其有天命然。」

translations.literal: It was because of Heaven's mandate.'
translations.idiomatic: It was because of Heaven's mandate.'

translations.literal: Master Chu said: 'Not so. The Poetry speaks of Xie being born from an egg, Hou Ji from a footprint, wishing to show that they had the intention of heavenly mandate and sincerity. Spirits and gods cannot complete themselves; they must be born through humans—how could they be born without fathers? One account says they had fathers, another says no fathers; transmit what is trustworthy as trustworthy, transmit doubt as doubt—therefore both accounts are given. Yao knew that Xie and Ji were both worthy men, born of Heaven, so he enfeoffed Xie with seventy li, and after more than ten generations reached Tang, who ruled All Under Heaven. Yao knew that Hou Ji's descendants would later rule, so he additionally enfeoffed him with a hundred li; his descendants lasted a thousand years, until King Wen possessed All Under Heaven. The Poetry transmission says: 'Tang's ancestor was Xie, born without a father. Xie's mother and her sisters were bathing in the Xuanhill waters when a swallow carried an egg and dropped it; Xie's mother got it, so she cherished it, mistakenly swallowed it, and thus gave birth to Xie. Xie was born and was worthy; Yao established him as Minister of Education, and gave him the surname Zi. Zi means 'this'; 'this' means increasingly great. The poets praised and eulogized him, saying 'The Yin fields are vast, heavenly mandate dark bird, descended and gave birth to Shang'. Shang means solid, Yin is the title. King Wen's ancestor was Hou Ji; Hou Ji was also born without a father. Hou Ji's mother was Jiang Yuan; she went out and saw giant footprints, stepped in them, became pregnant in her body, and gave birth to Hou Ji. Jiang Yuan considered him fatherless, lowly, and abandoned him on the road; oxen and sheep avoided and did not trample him. She carried him to the mountains; the mountains nourished him. Again she abandoned him in a great marsh; birds covered him with wings and fed him. Jiang Yuan was astonished, so knew he was a Son of Heaven, and took and raised him. Yao knew of his worthy talents, established him as Grand Minister of Agriculture, and gave him the surname Ji. Ji means root. The poets praised and eulogized him, saying 'At first he gave birth to the people', deeply cultivating and completing, and thus the beginning of Hou Ji's way.' Confucius said: 'In former times Yao commanded Xie to be of the Zi surname, because there would be Tang. He commanded Hou Ji to be of the Ji surname, because there would be King Wen. King Tai commanded Ji Li to receive the bright auspicious signs. Tai Bo went to Wu, thus establishing the source.' Heaven's mandate is difficult to speak of; only sages can perceive it. Shun, Yu, Xie, and Hou Ji were all Yellow Emperor descendants. The Yellow Emperor received Heaven's mandate and governed All Under Heaven; his virtue and favor deeply benefited later generations, therefore his descendants all again became established as Sons of Heaven—this is Heaven's reward for virtue. People do not know this, thinking it was from humble origins as commoners suddenly rising. How could commoners without cause suddenly rise and rule All Under Heaven? It was because of Heaven's mandate.'

sentences.zh: 「黃帝後世何王天下之久遠邪？」

translations.literal: 'Why did the Yellow Emperor's descendants rule All Under Heaven for such a long time?'
translations.idiomatic: 'Why did the Yellow Emperor's descendants rule All Under Heaven for such a long time?'

translations.literal: 'Why did the Yellow Emperor's descendants rule All Under Heaven for such a long time?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「傳云天下之君王為萬夫之黔首請贖民之命者帝，有福萬世。

translations.literal: He said: 'The tradition says that rulers of All Under Heaven who for ten thousand people redeem the people's fate are emperors, and have blessing for ten thousand generations.
translations.idiomatic: He said: 'The tradition says that rulers of All Under Heaven who for ten thousand people redeem the people's fate are emperors, and have blessing for ten thousand generations.

sentences.zh: 黃帝是也。

translations.literal: The Yellow Emperor was such.
translations.idiomatic: The Yellow Emperor was such.

sentences.zh: 五政明則修禮義，因天時舉兵征伐而利者王，有福千世。

translations.literal: When the five government affairs are clear, then cultivate ritual and righteousness, follow Heaven's seasons to raise troops and campaign successfully—that is ruling, with blessing for a thousand generations.
translations.idiomatic: When the five government affairs are clear, then cultivate ritual and righteousness, follow Heaven's seasons to raise troops and campaign successfully—that is ruling, with blessing for a thousand generations.

sentences.zh: 蜀王，黃帝後世也，至今在漢西南五千里，常來朝降，輸獻於漢，非以其先之有德，澤流後世邪？

translations.literal: The King of Shu was Yellow Emperor descendants; to this day in the southwest five thousand li from Han, they constantly come to court and pay tribute to Han—not because their ancestors had virtue that flowed to later generations?
translations.idiomatic: The King of Shu was Yellow Emperor descendants; to this day in the southwest five thousand li from Han, they constantly come to court and pay tribute to Han—not because their ancestors had virtue that flowed to later generations?

sentences.zh: 行道德豈可以忽秋哉！

translations.literal: How can practicing morality be neglected?
translations.idiomatic: How can practicing morality be neglected?

sentences.zh: 人君王者舉而觀之。

translations.literal: Ruling lords should raise this up and observe it.
translations.idiomatic: Ruling lords should raise this up and observe it.

sentences.zh: 漢大將軍霍子孟名光者，亦黃帝後世也。

translations.literal: The Han General Huo Qubing, named Guang, was also Yellow Emperor descendants.
translations.idiomatic: The Han General Huo Qubing, named Guang, was also Yellow Emperor descendants.

sentences.zh: 此可為博聞遠見者言，固難為淺聞者說也。

translations.literal: This can be told to those of broad learning and far sight; it is difficult to explain to those of shallow knowledge.
translations.idiomatic: This can be told to those of broad learning and far sight; it is difficult to explain to those of shallow knowledge.

sentences.zh: 何以言之？

translations.literal: Why speak thus?
translations.idiomatic: Why speak thus?

sentences.zh: 古諸侯以國為姓。

translations.literal: Ancient feudal lords took countries as surnames.
translations.idiomatic: Ancient feudal lords took countries as surnames.

sentences.zh: 霍者，國名也。

translations.literal: Huo was a country name.
translations.idiomatic: Huo was a country name.

sentences.zh: 武王封弟叔處於霍，後世晉獻公滅霍公，後世為庶民，往來居平陽。

translations.literal: King Wu enfeoffed his younger brother Shu at Huo; later generations Duke Xian of Jin extinguished Duke Huo, later generations became commoners, coming and going dwelling at Pingyang.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu enfeoffed his younger brother Shu at Huo; later generations Duke Xian of Jin extinguished Duke Huo, later generations became commoners, coming and going dwelling at Pingyang.

sentences.zh: 平陽在河東，河東晉地，分為衛國。

translations.literal: Pingyang is in Hedong, Hedong is Jin territory, divided into Wei country.
translations.idiomatic: Pingyang is in Hedong, Hedong is Jin territory, divided into Wei country.

sentences.zh: 以詩言之，亦可為周世。

translations.literal: Speaking with the Poetry, it can also be considered Zhou generations.
translations.idiomatic: Speaking with the Poetry, it can also be considered Zhou generations.

sentences.zh: 周起后稷，后稷無父而生。

translations.literal: Zhou arose from Hou Ji; Hou Ji was born without a father.
translations.idiomatic: Zhou arose from Hou Ji; Hou Ji was born without a father.

sentences.zh: 以三代世傳言之，后稷有父名高辛；

translations.literal: Speaking with the Three Dynasties genealogical transmissions, Hou Ji had a father named Gao Xin;
translations.idiomatic: Speaking with the Three Dynasties genealogical transmissions, Hou Ji had a father named Gao Xin;

sentences.zh: 高辛，黃帝曾孫。

translations.literal: Gao Xin was Yellow Emperor's great-grandson.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Xin was Yellow Emperor's great-grandson.

sentences.zh: 黃帝終始傳曰：『漢興百有餘年，有人不短不長，出（自）［白］燕之鄉，持天下之政，時有嬰兒主，欲行車。』

translations.literal: The Yellow Emperor beginning and end transmission says: 'When Han rose, more than a century, there will be a person not short not tall, coming from Yan's white region, holding All Under Heaven's government; at that time there will be an infant ruler, desiring to proceed by cart.'
translations.idiomatic: The Yellow Emperor beginning and end transmission says: 'When Han rose, more than a century, there will be a person not short not tall, coming from Yan's white region, holding All Under Heaven's government; at that time there will be an infant ruler, desiring to proceed by cart.'

sentences.zh: 霍將軍者，本居平陽（自）［白］燕。

translations.literal: General Huo originally dwelt at Pingyang in Yan.
translations.idiomatic: General Huo originally dwelt at Pingyang in Yan.

sentences.zh: 臣為郎時，與方士考功會旗亭下，為臣言。

translations.literal: When I was a gentleman attendant, with the fangshi I examined merit at the banner pavilion below, and he told me.
translations.idiomatic: When I was a gentleman attendant, with the fangshi I examined merit at the banner pavilion below, and he told me.

sentences.zh: 豈不偉哉！」

translations.literal: Is this not magnificent!'
translations.idiomatic: Is this not magnificent!'

translations.literal: He said: 'The tradition says that rulers of All Under Heaven who for ten thousand people redeem the people's fate are emperors, and have blessing for ten thousand generations. The Yellow Emperor was such. When the five government affairs are clear, then cultivate ritual and righteousness, follow Heaven's seasons to raise troops and campaign successfully—that is ruling, with blessing for a thousand generations. The King of Shu was Yellow Emperor descendants; to this day in the southwest five thousand li from Han, they constantly come to court and pay tribute to Han—not because their ancestors had virtue that flowed to later generations? How can practicing morality be neglected? Ruling lords should raise this up and observe it. The Han General Huo Qubing, named Guang, was also Yellow Emperor descendants. This can be told to those of broad learning and far sight; it is difficult to explain to those of shallow knowledge. Why speak thus? Ancient feudal lords took countries as surnames. Huo was a country name. King Wu enfeoffed his younger brother Shu at Huo; later generations Duke Xian of Jin extinguished Duke Huo, later generations became commoners, coming and going dwelling at Pingyang. Pingyang is in Hedong, Hedong is Jin territory, divided into Wei country. Speaking with the Poetry, it can also be considered Zhou generations. Zhou arose from Hou Ji; Hou Ji was born without a father. Speaking with the Three Dynasties genealogical transmissions, Hou Ji had a father named Gao Xin; Gao Xin was Yellow Emperor's great-grandson. The Yellow Emperor beginning and end transmission says: 'When Han rose, more than a century, there will be a person not short not tall, coming from Yan's white region, holding All Under Heaven's government; at that time there will be an infant ruler, desiring to proceed by cart.' General Huo originally dwelt at Pingyang in Yan. When I was a gentleman attendant, with the fangshi I examined merit at the banner pavilion below, and he told me. Is this not magnificent!'
